pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:0.5: 25. The training rule on taking back robe-cloth
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.2: At that time Venerable Upananda the Sakyan said to his brother’s student,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.3: “Come, let’s go wandering in the country.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.7: And he gave him a robe.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.9: that the Buddha was about to go wandering in the country.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.11: “Now I won’t go wandering with Venerable Upananda, but with the Buddha.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.14: he replied, “I’m not going with you, but with the Buddha.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.15: “Well, the robe I gave you is going with me,”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.16: and he just took it back in anger.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.17: That monk told other monks what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.18: And the monks of few desires complained and criticized Upananda,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.19: “How can Venerable Upananda give away a robe and then take it back in anger?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.20: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.21: “Is it true, Upananda, that you acted like this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.24: “… Foolish man, how can you give a robe to a monk and then take it back in anger?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.25: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.26: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.27.1: ‘If a monk himself gives a robe to a monk, but then, in anger, takes it back or has it taken back, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.10: one of the six kinds of robe-cloth, but not smaller than what can be transferred to another.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.14: if he takes it back himself, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.16: if he asks another, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.17: If he only asks once, then even if the other takes back many, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.18: The robe-cloth should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.19: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.20: (To be expanded as in [Relinquishment 1](pli-tv-bu-vb-np1:3.2.5--3.2.29), with appropriate substitutions.)
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.21: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth which I took back after giving it to a monk is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.24: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.25.1: If the other monk is fully ordained and he perceives him as such, and after giving him robe-cloth, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.26: If the other monk is fully ordained, but he is unsure of it, and after giving him robe-cloth, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.27: If the other monk is fully ordained, but he does not perceive him as such, and after giving him robe-cloth, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.28: If, after giving him another requisite, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.29: If, after giving robe-cloth or another requisite to a person who is not fully ordained, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.30: If the other monk is not fully ordained, but he perceives him as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.31: If the other monk is not fully ordained, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.32: If the other monk is not fully ordained, and he does not perceive him as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.34: if the other monk gives it back;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.35: if he takes it on trust from him;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.37: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.38: The fifth rule, the training rule on taking back robe-cloth, is finished.
